bibl.title: Lee Fong v. John Sullivan. Petition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: United States District Court for the District of Washington

div1.ab: IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, IN AND FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON. NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the application of Lee Fong for a writ of Habeas Corpus
div1.p: To the Hon. C.H.Hanford, Judge of the above entitled Court. The petition and complaint of Lee Fong respectfully shows; That he is of chinese birth and a resident of the City of Seattle in said District of Washington, where for seven (7) years last past he has been engaged in the occupation and business of a laundryman; that in the month of June last past, he leased the premises No.1410 east Fir Street, in the City of Seattle,State of Washington, for the purpose of coverting the same into a laundry, and therein carrying on the business of a laundry; that upon a building permit being issued by the proper authorized building inspector, in said City of Seattle, to whom had been submitted for inspection, and who approved of the specifications prepared for the conversion of said premises into a laundry, he incurred an expenditure of upwards of six hundred dollars ($600.) in making the necessary changes, additions and improvements in and on said premises required for the purpose of conducting said laundry business, all of which was done in accordance with said specifications for said laundry, approved and authorized as aforesaid by said building inspector in said City of Seattle. That after he had made said expenditures upon said authority, a petition from certain persons was addressed to the common Council of the City of Seattle, praying that said body should refuse its consent to, and prohibit the establishment of a laundry, designated in said petition as a "Chinese laundry", on said premises; that said Council, in compliance with said petition granted the prayer thereof and witheld its consent to this petitioner to establish or carry on his proposed laundry upon said premises

and that this petitioner had no hearing before said Council or their committee having said petition in charge; that the said Laundry has been so constructed and arranged as to be in a good sanatory condition, of which the health officer in said City of Seattle has delivered a certificate; and that all proper precautions were taken by the petitioner in the preparation of said premises for his laundry business, for the protection of property from injury or destruction by fire.

That notwithstanding the premises, your petitioner has been arrested upon a complaint, a copy of which is hereto attached, and made a part hereof, and that he is now unlawfully imprisoned, detained, confined and restrained of his liberty by John Sullivan, Chief of Police of said City of Seattle, at and in the City Jail of said City. That the said imprisonment, detention, confinement and restraint is illegal, and that the illegality thereof consists in this, to-wit; That said arrest and imprisonment & Sections six (6) and seven (7) of ordinance NO.710, of the City of Seattle, for the alleged violation of which this petitioner has been arrested, and is now imprisoned and restrained of his liberty as aforesaid, are in violation of, and in conflict with the constitution of the United States, and especially of the fifth (5th) and fourteenth (14th) amendments thereto; And also that said arrest and imprisonment is in violation of the treaty made and existing between the Government of the United States, and that of the Empire of China, the chief objection and opposition to the petitioner's laundry being that it is to be conducted by a chinaman, and that said ordinance which petitioner is charged with having violated, and the whole thereof, isnull and void.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner prays that a writ of Habeas Corpus may be granted directed to the said John Sullivan, Chief of police of the City of Seattle, commanding him to have the body of the said Lee Fong before your Honor at a time and place therein to be specified, to do and receive what shall then and there be considered right by your Honor concerning him, together with the time and cause of his said detention and said writ.
Done on the 2nd day of September 1902
div1.ab: State of Washington, County of King.
div1.p: Before me, a Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing in Seattle, said State, and duly qualified and commissioned, personally came Lee Fong the petitioner above named, being first duly sworn according to Law, did depose and say that he has had read to him the foregoing petition, knows the contents thereof and believe the same to be true
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 2nd day of September, 1902.
div1.ab: Frank B. Wiestling Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing in Seattle in said State.
The City of Seattle, VS. Lee Fong.
div1.p: F.E. Bryant being sworn says; That on the twenty nineth (29) day of August 1902, said Lee Fong did commit a mis-demeanor as follows, to-wit- By carrying on a public laundry without any permit from City council, said Lee Fong did wilfully and unlawfully at number 1410 Fir Street, said City of Seattle, establish, maintain and carry on a laundry within the corporate limits of said City of Seattle, and at said place, without first obtaining the consent of the City of Council of said City, the said laundry not being located in a building constructed either of brick, stone nor covered with a metal roof, all of which is contrary to ordinance No. 710, sections 6 and 7 of the City of Seattle entitled "An ordinance regulating the establishment and maintenance of public laundries and pulic was houses within the limits of the City of Seattle, approved February the sixth (6th,) 1886."
To the City Council of the City of Seattle,Washington.

Whereas, the building at No.1410 East Fir Street is being remodeled, and by additions and extensions is being fitted up for a Chinese Wash house or Laundry, and said building is not constructed either of Brick or Stone, nor is there any sewer connection, and it is dangerously near private residences,

THEREFORE, your petitioners, legal voters, tax payers or residents in the immediate vicinity respectfully and earnestly protest against having a Chinese Laundry established on the lot owned by Mr J. R. Miller at No. 1410 East Fir Street, and we ask you Honorable Body not to give your permit for the proposed Laundry, which we believe to be a menace to health, property valuation and fire protection, as in duty bound we will ever pray
div1.ab: Mrs W. T. Monroe 1404 East Fir Street, and other.
div1.p: Remonstrance against location of a Chinese Laundry at No. 1410 East Fir Street. Filed July 14, 1902, By G.K. Coryell, Deputy City Comptroller. Referred July 14. 1902 to H' & S' N Com. Reported July 21, 1902. Report adopted July 21, 1902.
Report that the Council refuse to grant the permit necessary.
div1.ab: J. E. Crighton, Chairman. Mullin. Murphy. Rude. J.C. Redward.
In the United States District Court FOR THE DISTRICT OF Washington Northern Division
In the Matter of the Petition and Complaint of Lee Fong for a writ of Habeas Corpus
FILED IN THE U. S. DISTRICT COURT, DIST. OF WASHINGTON.
J. M. Wiestling Attorney for Petitioner
